channel.title: Brisbane s calendar
channel.description: Brisbane City Council runs a range of classes, workshops, activities and events in Brisbane. Use our what's on calendar to search for concerts, sports and fitness, green events, markets, arts, culture, craft and more. Find out what's on today, this week and next month.

item.title: Parkinson Dragonboat and Multicultural Festival
item.description:
Forest Lake Parklands, Forest Lake
Ongoing through Thursday, June 6, 2013, 10am



The Parkinson Ward Multicultural and Dragon Boat Festival first held in 2010, is now an annual event on Brisbane's Multicultural calendar co-ordinated by the HAKKA Association, Forest Lake Rotary Club and the Queensland Dragonboat Federation and is proudly funded by the Brisbane City Council. 

As part of this festival, the day traditionally commences with a citizenship ceremony followed by a full program of multicultural entertainment, Dragonboat races with professional teams competing in the Lord Mayor's Dragonboat challenge and lots of multicultural stalls including a vast array of tantalising multicultural food. 

The Dragon Boat Festival commemorates the 2000 years' old story of the statesman and poet Chu Yuan, who in the 3rd century, in protest against a corrupt kingdom, threw himself into the Mi Lo River in despair.

Cost: Free
More info: www.angelaowentaylor.com.au…

item.title: Light Fantastic: Expo
item.description:
Tuesday, June 4, 2013, 10am – 5pm



For some there are two Brisbanes – the one before World Expo ‘88 and the one that emerged after. The enduring legacy of Expo ‘88 was not what the world saw of Brisbane, but what we saw of ourselves.

To celebrate the 25th anniversary of this landmark event, Light Fantastic: Expo ‘88 Parades Rewired will take visitors back in time to rediscover the magic of the Lunchtime and the Qantas Light Fantastic Parades that mesmerised crowds every day.

Unlike anything ever seen in Australia before, creating the parades was an intensive process. The resulting joy for thousands of visitors only hints at the enormous energy and collaboration needed to bring the ideas to life.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000
item.xCal:description:
For some there are two Brisbanes – the one before World Expo ‘88 and the one that emerged after. The enduring legacy of Expo ‘88 was not what the world saw of Brisbane, but what we saw of ourselves.
To celebrate the 25th anniversary of this landmark event, Light Fantastic: Expo ‘88 Parades Rewired will take visitors back in time to rediscover the magic of the Lunchtime and the Qantas Light Fantastic Parades that mesmerised crowds every day.
Unlike anything ever seen in Australia before, creating the parades was an intensive process. The resulting joy for thousands of visitors only hints at the enormous energy and collaboration needed to bring the ideas to life.
item.x-trumba:customfield: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000

item.title: Panoramas
item.description:
Tuesday, June 4, 2013, 10am – 5pm



Among the countless images taken since the introduction of photography to Australia in the 1860s, panoramas contain something special. Beyond the landscape, the photographs give an insight into life at different times in our city’s history when roads were rudimentary, horses gave way to early vehicles, and City Hall once towered over all.

Providing a fascinating insight into life in Brisbane over a 150 year span, the exhibition tracks Brisbane’s growth from a modest town nestled in the river’s curves to the modern city we know today.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000

item.title: The River: A history of Brisbane
item.description:
Tuesday, June 4, 2013, 10am – 5pm



As the defining symbol of our city, the wayward and beautiful Brisbane River had bought us opportunity, sanctuary and at times heartbreak.

The River: A History of Brisbane explores our ever-changing relationship with the river. From its importance to the land’s traditional owners, to its discovery that decided our capital’s location, and the industry that was born on its shores, the river has played a critical role in the growth of our city.

Connecting you to the stories of the city, the exhibition charts a compelling journey from Brisbane's earliest settlement through to the modern city we call home.

Cost: Free
Venue: Museum of Brisbane
Venue address: Brisbane City Hall, Adelaide and Ann Street, Brisbane, QLD 4000

item.title: Black Holes: Journey into the Unknown
item.description:
Tuesday, June 4, 2013, 1:30pm



Please check with the booking office that this show is running before attending. This show does not run if a dedicated school show has been booked.

Narrated by Geoffrey Rush, Black Holes is a show that imagines a place where time stands still; where the universal order breaks down, where the unimaginable becomes reality. A production of Melbourne Planetarium, distributed by Sky-Skan Inc.
Recommended for audiences over 6 years.

Duration: approximately 45 minutes, including a projected night sky tour.
Find out about prices and bookings.

Cost: Adult: $14.50, Children (under 15 years): $8.70, Concession: $12.30., Group prices: Family (2 Adults and 2 children): $39.00, Adult group (10 or more): $12.00, Children group (10 or more under 15 years): $8.00.
Bookings: Bookings are strongly recommended, especially during school holidays. Phone the booking office: 07 3403 2578
Venue: Sir Thomas Brisbane Planetarium
Venue address: Sir Thomas Brisbane Planetarium, Brisbane Botanic Gardens, Mt Coot-tha
Show type: General

item.title: Stars of the Pharaohs
item.description:
Tuesday, June 4, 2013, 3pm



Narrated by John Rhys-Davies. Travel to ancient Egypt to see how science was used to tell time, make a workable calendar, and align huge buildings. You'll learn about the connection the ancient Egyptians felt with the stars and various astronomical phenomena. You'll see some of the most spectacular temples and tombs recreated in their original splendour.
Recommended for audiences over 6 years.
Duration: approx. 50 minutes, including a projected night sky tour.
Find out about prices and bookings.
